column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Motomura (Japan): At the outset, I would\r
#Text=like to thank you, Mr.
#Text=President, for your initiative in\r
#Text=convening this open meeting as a follow-up to Security\r
#Text=Council resolution 1325 (2000), entitled "Women and\r
#Text=peace and security".
#Text=With the adoption of Council resolution 1325\r
#Text=(2000) in October 2000 and the subsequent statement\r
#Text=by the President of the Security Council in October last\r
#Text=year, the linkage between international peace and\r
#Text=security and gender issues has been increasingly\r
#Text=recognized throughout the international community.
#Text=Indeed, there is a growing awareness of the negative\r
#Text=impact that armed conflict has on women and children\r
#Text=in particular and of the importance of women's\r
#Text=participation in post-conflict peace processes.
#Text=On the other hand, what is now needed is more\r
#Text=detailed information and analysis of concrete examples,\r
#Text=as well as recommendations and practical measures.
#Text=My delegation, therefore, looks forward to the results\r
#Text=of the study conducted by Ms.
#Text=Angela King, Special\r
#Text=Adviser on Gender Issues and Advancement of\r
#Text=Women.
#Text=We also look forward to the results of the\r
#Text=assessments by the two independent experts appointed\r
#Text=by the United Nations Development Fund for Women\r
#Text=on the impact of armed conflict on women and the role\r
#Text=of women in peace-building, as well as the report of\r
#Text=the Secretary-General to be submitted later this year.
#Text=The conclusions of these studies and reports will\r
#Text=be crucial in terms of giving direction and providing\r
#Text=concrete methodologies for the steady implementation\r
#Text=of resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=Allow me to briefly describe the basic views and\r
#Text=concrete actions taken by my Government as regards\r
#Text=gender mainstreaming in the area of conflicts and\r
#Text=peacekeeping.
#Text=First, I would like to draw special\r
#Text=attention to the active role Afghan women are playing\r
#Text=the post-conflict reconstruction of their country.
#Text=As\r
#Text=Prime Minister Koizumi stated at the international\r
#Text=conference on reconstruction assistance to Afghanistan,\r
#Text=held in Tokyo earlier this year, one of the highest\r
#Text=priorities of Japan's assistance for Afghanistan's\r
#Text=reconstruction is the empowerment of women.
#Text=Japan has thus sent an expert to the Ministry of\r
#Text=Women's Affairs and has extended financial support\r
#Text=for the establishment of women's centres in\r
#Text=Afghanistan.
#Text=Moreover, in February, Japan set up the\r
#Text=Advisory Council on Assistance to Women in\r
#Text=Afghanistan, taking into account the proposals of the\r
#Text=Security Council, and is determined to continuously\r
#Text=support the tremendous efforts the Afghan women\r
#Text=themselves are making to restore peace in their country.
#Text=Secondly, with the mandates of peacekeeping\r
#Text=operations becoming more multidimensional, it is\r
#Text=increasingly important that women's views are\r
#Text=integrated into their respective activities.
#Text=I am pleased\r
#Text=to note that earlier this year the Japanese Government\r
#Text=for the first time dispatched seven women\r
#Text=peacekeepers to the United Nations peacekeeping\r
#Text=operations in East Timor, where they are now engaged\r
#Text=in coordination activities in such areas as\r
#Text=communication and translation.
#Text=In addition, an\r
#Text=increasing number of Japanese women who are United\r
#Text=Nations staff members are working in the civilian\r
#Text=components of peacekeeping missions.
#Text=The\r
#Text=Government of Japan will continuously strive to\r
#Text=increase the participation of women in peace operations\r
#Text=in various areas.
#Text=Thirdly, given the particular importance of gender\r
#Text=mainstreaming in the field, the Japanese Government\r
#Text=supported the recommendation of the Special\r
#Text=Committee on Peacekeeping Operations, which was\r
#Text=endorsed by the General Assembly, that "the work of\r
#Text=gender focal points should have the proper back-up in\r
#Text=the Secretariat".
#Text=In this context, my delegation hopes\r
#Text=that, as stated in General Assembly resolution 56/293\r
#Text=in June this year, the Secretariat will develop and\r
#Text=clearly explain a coherent policy on gender\r
#Text=mainstreaming in all United Nations peacekeeping\r
#Text=activities.
#Text=In October we will celebrate the second\r
#Text=anniversary of the adoption of Security Council\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=My delegation hopes that the\r
#Text=entire discussion at today's meeting will prove useful\r
#Text=in the ongoing efforts to follow up the resolution and\r
#Text=will be fully reflected in the report of the Secretary-\r
#Text=General.
#Text=In closing, let me assure you, Mr.
#Text=President, of\r
#Text=Japan's readiness to contribute to the goals of this\r
#Text=important resolution in cooperation with all other\r
#Text=interested Member States.
